Hi all,

Thanks for the feedback so far. There are a few issues raised and =
I'll
try to cover all of them. Apologies for the length of the post.

First=
ly I did of course mean tabu search - easily confused terms I
think you'll =
agree.

Some general themes then:

1) Speciating by comparing new genomes (=
I call them offspring from
here) with each species in turn.

Generally I li=
ke this, but there are some potential side effects I'm
unsure about. e.g. i=
f the species overlap in the encoding space then
any offspring that exist i=
n an overlapping region will always get
assigned to the species that comes =
first, this leaves an empty bite
shaped region (a crecent shape in 2D space=
) in the second species.
Ultimately you might end up where the two regions =
are almost exactly
the same (the exemplars are very close) and so the genom=
es in the
second species are all in a very thin cresent formation. In fact =
you
might have several species where each one is a cresent shape on the
edg=
e of the previous one.

This in turn might affect some of our other mechani=
sms. e.g. if
species number 2's genomes are as fit as number 1's then we ex=
pect
them to contain about the same number of genomes (through fitness
shar=
ing), but in fact most of species 2's offspring end up in the
first species=
. Later on (in sharpneat at least) we might take N% of
the best genomes in =
each species as the parents for the next
generation, but because the total =
number in each species has been
distorted, that N% is similarly distorted -=
 thus species 2 is
potentially (depending how you make the calculations)
un=
der-represented as a parent for the next generation of offspring.

The expl=
icit clustering algorithm I described is in fact called
k-means clustering.=
 So if we use k-means (or some other standard
approach) as a way of dividin=
g our genomes into clusters before we
start the main NEAT loop running we l=
essen the problem of overlapping
regions between species. We can still use =
the same speciation
technique in the main loop and perhaps periodically re-=
speciate using
k-means if we think overlap is occuring, if there is some ea=
sy way of
detecting the amount of overlap.

2) In sharpneat v1 I actually t=
est offspring against their parent
species first (note. there are two paren=
t species in cross species
breeding, but normally only one), and *then* tes=
t against every other
species in turn. I didn't properly consider what this=
 means when I
wrote the code. Firstly it means performance is improved beca=
use most
offspring will in fact be placed in their parent's species, thus n=
o
further comparisons are necessary. However it introduces the
possibility =
(likelihood?) of species overlapping to a large degree,
they could even rep=
resent the exact same region in the encoding space.
Ultimately they may dri=
ft apart but in the mean time they are both
searching the same fitness spac=
e which is precisely what speciation is
trying to avoid.  Potentially all s=
pecies could all get stuck on some
local maximum (=3D bad).


So at this po=
int a better strategy than both mine and Ken's is to use
Ken's approach of =
comparing species in turn (with the species in a
fixed order between genera=
tions) but to avoid cresent shaped species
(if indeed that is what happens)=
 by using k-means at the outset and
periodically, e.g. when the species cou=
nt goes outside of some limits
or every N generations.

3) Petar, regarding=
 your suggestion about creating a representative
genome for each species. T=
his is potentially equivalent to calculating
the center center of the regio=
n in space defined by the genomes, in
fact if you average the weight of con=
nections with the same ID you
calculate the center of mass of the genomes. =
So in 2D the exemplar is
currently in the center of a circle, but the bulk =
of the other genomes
may be clustered around one edge of the circle (becaus=
e of some local
maximum say), thus the center of 'mass' is in fact not in t=
he center
but somewhere towards (or within) the cluster. So ff we did ancho=
r our
species for their lifetime this would become far more likely.

BTW th=
is center of mass of genomes is effectively what k-means
clustering is doin=
g, we calculate the average distance from each
genome in a cluster; for eac=
h cluster; and assign a genome to the
cluster it is nearest to - that is, i=
t gets assigned to the cluster
whose *center of mass* is closest. We could =
calculate the center of
mass directly to reduce the number of comparisons w=
e make, but there
are some reasons not to - (A) Whenever we re-assign a gen=
ome from one
cluster to another we move the center of mass of both of those=

clusters, thus they would need recalculating (although you could avoid
rec=
alculating right way). And (B) Calculating the center of mass
requires us t=
o to define a coordinate system, which admitedly would be
easy, it's just a=
n array of numbers. But it's even easier to plug in a
function that take tw=
o genomes and returns the distance between them
as a single number. The fun=
ction effectively defines a distance metric
and we can plug in and try alte=
rnative distance metrics (euclidean,
manhattan, kens original [I'm calling =
it ken's canonical distance
metric :) ] )

4) Anchoring of species. I think=
 if we were to try tabu search we
would need to anchor the species. Otherwi=
se if a species drifts then
we have only partially searched some regions an=
d we need some means of
recording that information. What you end of with is=
 a sort of density
map of the search space where density represents how muc=
h searching
has occured in a given region. It's just a lot simpler if the s=
earch
regions are fixed/distinct chunks of space that we flag as being
sear=
ch or not searched (not exhaustively searched, but enough that we
decided t=
o move on). There is still a problem in that as the compat.
threshold varie=
s the radius of each species/region is changing - so
they're not actually f=
ixed chunks but varying in size.

I can see the pros of allowing species to=
 drift; following the species
champ. But maybe it's not so bad to acnhor. W=
hat might happen is that
as genome smove towards some fitter space they end=
 up on the edge of
the species/region they are in. Now their offspring are =
outside the
region, they form a new species because they are not close enou=
gh to
an existing one.  If we now re-speciate using k-means (rather than th=
e
current approach of increasing the compat. threshold) then the new/fit
cl=
uster will form a new species with a new anchor, the old
species/regions ar=
e thrown away completely. 

The idea needs a bit of work/thought but I thin=
k it might work. So in
conclusion k-means clustering potentially gives you =
less species
overlap (in sharpneat's case) or less cresent shaped species w=
ith a
distorted size relative to their fitness (in Ken's case). And along
w=
ith anchored species exemplars it gives you an easy(er) way if doing
tabu s=
earch.

Colin.
